document.title: Gradients and Hessians in Hilbert spaces

para.p:
Let
( X ,
⟨ ⋅ , ⋅ ⟩
)
be a real Hilbert space. The Riesz representation theorem says that the mapping

Math.text: Phi * x * y = list@(list@(y, x), Phi) colon X to X ^ *

para.p:
is an isometric isomorphism. Let
U
be a nonempty open subset of
X
and let
: f
→ U R
be differentiable, with derivative
:
f ′
U →
⁢ L
( X ; R )
=
X *
. The gradient of
f
is the function
:
⁢ grad f
→ U X
defined by

Math.text: grad * f = Phi ^ (- 1) compose f ^ prime

para.p:
Thus, for
∈ x U
,
⁢ grad f
( x )
is the unique element of
X
satisfying

Math.text: formulae@(list@(grad * f * x, y) = f ^ prime * x * y, y element-of X)

para.p:
Because
:
Φ
- 1
→
X *
X
is continuous, if
∈ f
⁢
C 1
( U ; R )
then
∈
⁢ grad f
⁢ C
( U ; X )
, being a composition of two continuous functions.

For example, let
T
be a bounded self-adjoint operator on
X
and define
: f
→ X R
by

Math.text: formulae@(f * x = (1 / 2) * list@(T * x, x), x element-of X)

para.p:
For
∈
x , h
X
,

Math.tex: f(x+h)-f(x)=\frac{1}{2}\left\langle Tx,h\right\rangle+\frac{1}{2}\left\langle Th% ,x\right\rangle+\frac{1}{2}\left\langle Th,h\right\rangle=\left\langle Tx,h% \right\rangle+\frac{1}{2}\left\langle Th,h\right\rangle.
Math.text: f * (x + h) - f * x = (1 / 2) * list@(T * x, h) + (1 / 2) * list@(T * h, x) + (1 / 2) * list@(T * h, h) = list@(T * x, h) + (1 / 2) * list@(T * h, h)

para.p: Thus

Math.text: absolute-value@(f * (x + h) - f * x - list@(T * x, h)) = (1 / 2) * absolute-value@(list@(T * h, h)) less= (1 / 2) * norm@(T) * (norm@(h)) ^ 2 = o * norm@(h)

para.p:
which shows that
f
is differentiable at
h
, with
=
⁢
f ′
( x )
( y )
⟨
⁢ T x
, y ⟩
. Thus by (),

⁢ grad f
( x )
⁢ T x
.

For example, let
∈ T
⁢ L
( X ; X )
, let
∈ h X
, and define
: f
→ X R
by

Math.text: formulae@(f * x = (1 / 2) * (norm@(T * x - h)) ^ 2, x element-of X)

para.p: We calculate that

Math.text: formulae@(grad * f * x = T ^ * * T * x - T ^ * * h, x element-of X)

para.p:
For
∈
x 0
X
, define

Math.text: formulae@(phi * t = exponential@(- t * T ^ * * T) * x _ 0 + ((integral _ 0) ^ t)@(exponential@(- (t - s) * T ^ * * T) * T ^ * * h * differential-d@(s)), t >= 0)

para.p:
It is proved 1 1 footnote 1 cf. J.W. Neuberger, A Sequence of Problems on Semigroups, p. 51, Problem 195. that
ϕ
satisfies

Math.text: formulae@(phi ^ prime * t = - grad * f * phi * t, phi * 0 = x _ 0)

para.p:
For a function
: F
→ X X
, we say that
F
is
L
Lipschitz if

Math.text: formulae@(norm@(F * x - F * y) less= list@(L * norm@(x - y), x), y element-of X)

para.p: The following is a useful inequality for functions whose gradients are Lipschitz. 2 2 footnote 2 Juan Peypouquet, Convex Optimization in Normed Spaces: Theory, Methods and Examples, p. 15, Lemma 1.30.

If
: f
→ X R
is differentiable and
:
⁢ grad f
→ X X
is
L
Lipschitz, then

Math.text: formulae@(f * y less= list@(f * x + list@(grad * f * x, y - x) + (L / 2) * (norm@(y - x)) ^ 2, x), y element-of X)

para.p:
Let
= h
- y x
and define
: g
→
[ 0 , 1 ]
R
by
=
⁢ g
( t )
⁢ f
(
+ x
⁢ t h
)
. By the chain rule, for
0 < t < 1
,

Math.text: g ^ prime * t = f ^ prime * (x + t * h) * h = list@(grad * f * (x + t * h), h)

para.p: Thus by the fundamental theorem of calculus,

Math.text: ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(list@(grad * f * (x + t * h), h) * differential-d@(t)) = ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(g ^ prime * t * differential-d@(t)) = g * 1 - g * 0 = f * (x + h) - f * x = f * y - f * x

para.p:
and so, using the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality and the fact that
⁢ grad f
is
L
Lipschitz,

Math.text: f * y - f * x = ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(list@((grad * f * (x + t * h) - grad * f * x) + grad * f * x, h) * differential-d@(t))
f * y - f * x
absent = ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(list@((grad * f * (x + t * h) - grad * f * x) + grad * f * x, h) * differential-d@(t))
absent = list@(grad * f * x, h) * d * t + ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(list@(grad * f * (x + t * h) - grad * f * x, h) * differential-d@(t))
absent = list@(grad * f * x, h) * d * t + ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(list@(grad * f * (x + t * h) - grad * f * x, h) * differential-d@(t))
absent less= list@(grad * f * x, h) + ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(norm@(grad * f * (x + t * h) - grad * f * x) * norm@(h) * differential-d@(t))
absent less= list@(grad * f * x, h) + ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(norm@(grad * f * (x + t * h) - grad * f * x) * norm@(h) * differential-d@(t))
absent less= list@(grad * f * x, h) + ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(L * norm@(t * h) * norm@(h) * differential-d@(t))
absent less= list@(grad * f * x, h) + ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(L * norm@(t * h) * norm@(h) * differential-d@(t))
absent = list@(grad * f * x, y - x) + (L / 2) * (norm@(y - x)) ^ 2
absent = list@(grad * f * x, y - x) + (L / 2) * (norm@(y - x)) ^ 2

para.p: proving the claim. ∎

Let
U

X

C 2

Math.text: formulae@(f ^ prime2 * x * u * v = list@(v, (grad * f) ^ prime * x * u), formulae@(x element-of list@(U, u), v element-of X))

That

:

and because

If
∈ f
⁢
C 2
( U ; R )

∈
⁢ grad f
⁢
C 1
( U ; X )

⁢ grad f
the Hessian of
f
, 4 4 footnote 4 cf. R. A. Tapia, The differentiation and integration of nonlinear operators, pp. 45–101, in Nonlinear Functional Analysis and Applications (Louis B. Rall, ed.)

Math.text: formulae@(Hess * f = (grad * f) ^ prime, U to L * list@(X, X))

para.p: and () then reads

Math.tex: f^{\prime\prime}(x)(u)(v)=\left\langle v,\mathrm{Hess}\,f(x)(u)\right\rangle,% \qquad x\in U,\quad u,v\in X.
Math.text: formulae@(f ^ prime2 * x * u * v = list@(v, Hess * f * x * u), formulae@(x element-of list@(U, u), v element-of X))

para.p:
Furthermore, it is a fact that if
∈ f

C 2
( U ; R )

∈ x U
, the bilinear form

Math.text: open-interval@(u, v) maps-to f ^ prime2 * x * u * v

is symmetric. 5 5 footnote 5 Serge Lang, Real and Functional Analysis, third ed., p. 344, Theorem 5.3. Thus, for
∈ x U
and
∈
u , v
X

Math.text: list@(v, Hess * f * x * u) = list@(u, Hess * f * x * v)

Now, using that
⟨ ⋅ , ⋅ ⟩

X

∈
(

*

para.p: so

Math.text: list@(v, Hess * f * x * u) = list@(v, (Hess * f * x) ^ * * u)

If
x

has Lebesgue measure

and is meager.

For Banach spaces
Y
and
Z

T *

A function
∈ f

itself has a Cauchy subsequence.

Often when speaking about ordinary differential equations in
R d
, we deal with differentiable functions whose derivatives are locally Lipschitz.
R d
has the Heine-Borel property: a subset
K
of
R d
is compact if and only if
K
is closed and bounded. In fact no infinite dimensional Banach space has the Heine-Borel property. 9 9 footnote 9 Some Fréchet spaces have the Heine-Borel property, like the space of holomorphic functions on the open unit disc, which is what Montel’s theorem says. Thus a locally Lipschitz function need not be Lipschitz on a bounded subset of
X
. (On a compact set, the set is covered by balls on which the function is Lipschitz, and then the function is Lipschitz on the compact set with Lipschitz constant equal to the maximum of finitely many Lipschitz constants on the balls.) We denote by
C
the set of function
: f
→ X R
that are differentiable and such that for each bounded subset
A
of
X
, the restriction of
⁢ grad f
to
A
is Lipschitz.

The mountain pass theorem 10 10 footnote 10 Lawrence C. Evans, Partial Differential Equations, p. 480, Theorem 2; Antonio Ambrosetti and David Arcoya Álvarez, An Introduction to Nonlinear Functional Analysis and Elliptic Problems, p. 48, §5.3. states that if (i)
∈ I C
, (ii)
I
satisfies the Palais-Smale condition, (iii)

0
, (iv) there are
>

r

>

and

para.p: We prove that a critical point of a differentiable convex function on an open convex set is a minimum. 11 11 footnote 11 N. A. Bobylev, S. V. Emel’yanov, and S. K. Korovin, Geometrical Methods in Variational Problems, p. 39, Theorem 2.1.4.

We call a function
: F
→ X X
β
co-coercive if

Math.text: list@(F * x - F * y, x - y) >= beta * (norm@(F * x - F * y)) ^ 2

para.p: We prove conditions under which the gradient of a differentiable convex function is co-coercive. 13 13 footnote 13 Juan Peypouquet, Convex Optimization in Normed Spaces: Theory, Methods and Examples, p. 40, Theorem 3.13.

Let
: f
→ X R
be differentiable and convex and let
> L 0
. Then
⁢ grad f
is
L
Lipschitz if and only if
⁢ grad f
is
1 L
co-coercive.

⁢ grad f
is

∈ x X
, define

by

Math.text: h _ x * y = f * y - f ^ prime * x * y = f * y - list@(grad * f * x, y)

para.p: and applying (),

+ (1 / (2 * L)) * (norm@(grad * f * x - grad * f * y)) ^ 2 * (norm@(v _ epsilon)) ^ 2
+ (1 / (2 * L)) * (norm@(grad * f * x - grad * f * y)) ^ 2 * (norm@(v _ epsilon)) ^ 2

+ (1 / (2 * L)) * (norm@(grad * f * x - grad * f * y)) ^ 2
+ (1 / (2 * L)) * (norm@(grad * f * x - grad * f * y)) ^ 2

Math.text: 0 less= list@(grad * f * x - grad * f * y, x) + list@(grad * f * y - grad * f * x, y)

(- (1 / L) * (norm@(grad * f * x - grad * f * y)) ^ 2) + 2 * R * epsilon
